item.title: Three Federal Officers Injured in Los Angeles Protests, D.H.S. Says
item.description: One Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer was injured after being hit in the head with a rock, and two Federal Protective Services officers were also injured, the department said.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Ted Soqui/Sipa, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Los Angeles students walked out of school and marched to the federal building to rally and protest against ICE on Friday.

item.title: Trump Files Final Plans for White House Ballroom
item.description: The president is seeking quick approval despite legal challenges and backlash over his demolition of the East Wing.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of the demolished East Wing of the White House in Washington in December.

item.title: Judge Orders U.S. to Facilitate Return of College Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor said last month that ICE had made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Massdeportationdefense.Org, via Reuters
item.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza, a Massachusetts college student, was mistakenly deported in November to Honduras.

item.title: Judge Orders ICE to Let Clergy Give Communion to Detained Migrants on Ash Wednesday
item.description: A Catholic nonprofit and several clergy said immigration authorities had unlawfully blocked its members for months from providing pastoral care at an ICE facility in Broadview, Ill.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Adam Gray/Associated Press
item.media:description: People marched to the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Broadview, Ill., in October.

item.title: Trump Says Regime Change Would Be the ‘Best Thing’ for Iran
item.description: The president has been steadily building up U.S. military forces in the Middle East and threatening another strike on the country if the government does not abandon its nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump boarding Air Force One at Fort Bragg in North Carolina, on Friday.

item.title: Why Are More Congress Members Retiring or Not Seeking Re-election in 2026?
item.description: For many senators and House members, the job isn’t what it used to be.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Ramping Up Election Attacks, Trump Does Not Let Reality Get in His Way
item.description: President Trump increases his attacks when he fears an election loss. With midterm elections approaching, he has gone into overdrive as Republicans face potential losses.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Who Is Jeremy Carl, Trump’s Nominee to Lead the State Department?
item.description: Jeremy Carl, President Trump’s nominee to lead the State Department’s outreach to international organizations, had a rough confirmation hearing, but he stood by his views on “whiteness.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremy Carl, nominee to be an Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, at a U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington D.C., this week.

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.description: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Homeland Security is expanding its efforts to identify Americans who oppose Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: Ocasio-Cortez Offers a Working-Class Vision in Munich, With a Few Stumbles
item.description: Speaking at Europe’s largest security conference, she tied income inequality to the rise of authoritarians and offered a forceful rebuttal to President Trump’s worldview. She also had some shaky moments.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York spoke at two panels on Friday at the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: White House Outlines Trump Plan for Shipping Industry
item.description: President’s proposal says maritime business “is critical for national and economic security.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Philadelphia shipyard owned by Hanwha, a South Korean conglomerate. The company bought the shipyard under the Biden administration and plans to expand it.

item.title: Department of Homeland Security Shuts Down, Though Essential Work Continues
item.description: Though funding for the department ran out early Saturday, officials said its essential functions would continue.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: During previous shutdowns, the Transportation Security Administration saw a spike in resignations because employees were required to report to work without being paid.

item.title: Virginia’s Top Court Clears Path for Democratic Push to Redraw House Map
item.description: The State Supreme Court allowed a spring statewide referendum that is necessary for Democrats to redraw Virginia’s congressional map before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Dennis MacDonald, via Alamy
item.media:description: The Virginia Supreme Court left unsettled the legality of a bid by the state’s Democratic-led legislature to overhaul the House map in the party’s favor.

item.title: Trump Administration Revokes Deportation Protections for Yemenis
item.description: It is the latest restriction of the Temporary Protected Status program, which has allowed people fleeing unrest in their home countries to live and work in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem during a cabinet meeting at the White House last month.

item.title: Texas University Closes Exhibition With Anti-ICE Artwork
item.description: The exhibition at the University of North Texas by a Mexican-born artist included the language “Immigration and Cruelty Enforcement.”
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: As Diplomats Talk, Pentagon Prepares for Possible War With Iran
item.description: President Trump threatened to strike Iran, but the military has needed time to build up its forces in the region.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Tehran walk on U.S. and Israeli flags during a march to commemorate the 47th anniversary of Iran’s Islamic revolution. Senior officials said Mr. Trump had not decided whether he would strike Iran.

item.title: Justice Department Sues Harvard for Admissions Records
item.description: The Trump administration appears to have renewed its pressure campaign against Harvard since President Trump backtracked this month on a possible settlement with the Ivy League school.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lawsuit is the second government action targeting Harvard in the two weeks since President Trump’s sudden reversal of his position on a potential deal to end the administration’s pressure campaign on the university.

item.title: Congress Leaves DC as DHS Shuts Down
item.description: Despite a deadlock over funding for the agency, lawmakers left town and left Democratic and White House negotiators to try to work out a deal in their absence.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congress left Washington for a weeklong recess despite not reaching a deal to fund the Department of Homeland Security.

item.title: Trump’s Minnesota Retreat Points to the Power of Public Anger
item.description: The withdrawal came as polls show Americans opposing the president’s immigration tactics, and as some Republican lawmakers began to find ways to distance themselves.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration said on Thursday that it was winding down its deployment of immigration agents to Minnesota.

item.title: Bessent Pushes Senate on Fed Confirmation Amid Backlash Over Criminal Inquiry
item.description: President Trump’s effort to get Kevin M. Warsh confirmed as the next Federal Reserve chair has been complicated by a criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The comments by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent underscore the urgency the Trump administration is feeling as it looks to replace the Federal Reserve chair.

item.title: U.S. Transfers Thousands of ISIS Prisoners to Iraq From Syria
item.description: The moves appear to highlight lingering doubts in Washington about the new Syrian government’s ability to ensure security.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Orhan Qereman/Reuters
item.media:description: U.S. military vehicles in Qamishli, Syria, escorted buses transporting Islamic State detainees to Iraq this month.

item.title: Another Government Shutdown? Here’s What Travelers Should Know.
item.description: It was not immediately clear whether passengers would face delays at airport security checkpoints in the coming days if a government shutdown does occur.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Lynne Sladky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Employees of the Transportation Security Administration, which is part of the Department of Homeland Security, must work without pay during a shutdown. It’s still unclear if or when travelers would feel the effects.

item.title: A D.H.S. Shutdown Looms. Bruised Minnesotans Urge Their Parties to Dig In.
item.description: Congressional Democrats say they will approve no money for the Department of Homeland Security without guardrails on immigration agents. Their voters in Minnesota are demanding no less.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The surge of immigration agents may be receding in Minneapolis, but protesters in the city want Democrats to hold firmly against Homeland Security funding.

item.title: Trump Wants Smithsonian to Create a Different Official Portrait
item.description: The painted portrait from President Trump’s first term was completed more than four years ago, but never unveiled. Now he wants the National Portrait Gallery to commission a new one.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Michael Temchine for The New York Times

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.description: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty classroom at the high school in Williston, N.D., during an outbreak of measles there last year.

item.title: Local Sheriffs Voice Frustration With ICE
item.description: As tension builds over immigration raids around the country, local law enforcement officials are increasingly speaking out. We followed a sheriff from Maine who lambasted ICE operations in his state as he traveled to Washington to share concerns with lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Ben Laffin, Singeli Agnew and Amogh Vaz
item.media:credit: Brent McDonald/The New York Times
item.media:description: On Feb. 3, Cumberland County, Maine Sheriff Kevin Joyce was on Capitol Hill meeting with lawmakers about tensions he experienced with immigration enforcement in his state.

item.title: Venezuela’s Natural Gas, Not Oil, Might Be a Big Early Prize
item.description: The South American country has natural gas that could be extracted and exported quickly, but U.S. sanctions, which are now being eased, have stymied development.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Daniel Wood
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: A liquefied natural gas terminal in Trinidad and Tobago, a country that has the infrastructure that Venezuela needs to bring its vast reserves of natural gas to market.

item.title: Why Did the Courts Do That? Let Him Explain.
item.description: Adam Liptak, The Times’s chief legal affairs correspondent, is writing a new weekly newsletter, The Docket, to help demystify the justice system.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
